titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Day Family Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday February 14, 2019 at 08:02

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The Day family papers consist of correspondence, account books, diaries, journals, lectures, manuscripts, notes, sermons, and related papers of the Day family, 1767-1929. The personal lives, academic activities, and professional careers of several family members are documented, including Reverend Jeremiah Day (1737-1806), Reverend Jeremiah Day (1773-1867), Henry Noble Day (1808-1890), Mills Day (1783-1812), and others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of children of Thomas M. Day, 1929. Gift of Harold L. Leupp, 1936. Gift of Sherman Day and Henry V. Day, 1939. Gift of Emma Thacher, 1943. Gift of Schaffer Library, Union College, 1988. Gift of Anne Day Thacher, 2003. Gift of Thomas Mcfadden, 2016.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Day Family Papers (MS 175). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in ten series and three additions: I. Correspondence, 1795-1905. II. Jeremiah Day, (1737-1806). III. Jeremiah Day, (1773-1867). IV. Thomas Day, (1777-1855). V. Thomas Mills Day, (1817-1905). VI. Henry Noble Day, (1800-1903). VII. Mills Day, (1783-1812). VIII. Jeremiah Day, (1773-1867): Presidential Papers, 1805-1860. IX. Marble Family, 1815-1845. X. Miscellaneous, 1789-1929.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Day family of Connecticut traces its American origins to Robert Day (1604-1648), who settled in Massachusetts in 1634 and shortly thereafter relocated in Connecticut. Several generations of family members, many of whom are represented in this collection, were educated at Yale University and later taught or held administrative positions there. Many family members chose a religious career, including Jeremiah Day (1737-1806), Jeremiah Day (1773-1867), Henry Noble Day (1808-1890), and Mills Day (1783-1812). Brief genealogical charts for the families of Jeremiah Day (1737-1806) and Thomas Day (1777-1855) are locatedhere.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Day family papers consist of correspondence, account books, diaries, journals, lectures, manuscripts, notes, sermons, and related papers of the Day family, 1767-1929. The personal lives, academic activities, and professional careers of several family members are documented, including Reverend Jeremiah Day (1737-1806), Reverend Jeremiah Day (1773-1867), Henry Noble Day (1808-1890), Mills Day (1783-1812), and others.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: For a listing of correspondents with the Day family, please consult theCorrespondents Index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains letters of Day family members, with the bulk of correspondence relating to Thomas Day. The letters are largely personal in nature, relating to family concerns, although Thomas Day's activities as secretary of state in Connecticut are noted. Thomas Day's six daughters exchanged letters from the 1830s to the 1860s. His son, Thomas Mills Day, wrote often from Europe and the Middle East during 1850-1851.

The earliest letters in the collection appear to be written to and by Reverend Jeremiah Day (1737-1806), a minister in New Preston, Connecticut, and the letters relate to religious topics and include items exchanged with Jonathan Edwards (the younger).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains an estate inventory, journals, poems, sermons, and theological papers written by Reverend Jeremiah Day from 1759-1804, and includes other family papers from later dates. Jeremiah Day's sermons date from 1759-1804, and his theological papers include student papers written at Yale University in the 1750s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of account books, diaries, journals, lecture notebooks, manuscripts of books, sermons, and other papers of Reverend Jeremiah Day dating from 1797-1838. Papers relating directly to Day's service as president of Yale are arranged in Series VIII. Jeremiah Day, (1773-1867): Presidential Papers, 1805-1860.

Diaries contain information on the years 1797-1801 and journals focus on the years 1799-1802, with information through 1845. Lecture notebooks and outlines contain Day's thoughts on the subject "Natural Philosophy," while manuscripts for books such as An Introduction to Algebra ... , The Mathematical Principles ... , Treatise of Plane Trigonometry , Edwards on the Will , Self Determining Power of the Will , and others are included in this series. Sermons prepared and delivered by Reverend Day from 1799-1838 are also arranged here.

unittitle.title: Self Determining Power of the Will
Self Determining Power of the Will

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a small quantity of personal and financial material relating to Thomas Day, and includes records for the Hartford Grammar School, 1811-1834.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains several account books (1852-1905) for Day as well as an eight volume group of diaries (1865-1871, 1875).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains account books (1800-1903), business papers (1824-1913), sermons (1833-1864), correspondence (1848-1849, 1863-1884), and other papers relating to Day and his family, including his wife Jane Louisa Marble Day.

did.unittitle: Lists of subscribers to American Education Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains account books, sermons, and other papers of Day, who graduated from Yale in 1803 and served as a tutor at Yale College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, student papers and materials, notes, records, speeches, and other items documenting Day's academic career and presidency of Yale University (1817-1846). Additional papers of Jeremiah Day are arranged in Series III. Jeremiah Day, (1773-1867). For official records of the Yale University President's Office see the finding aid for YRG-2.

did.unittitle: Inaugural address of Theodore Dwight Woolsey

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the papers of several members of the Marble family, who married into the Day family in the 1800s. Jane Louisa Marble Day, the wife of Henry Noble Day, and other family members are represented in this series.

did.unittitle: Diary fragments (multiple authors including Adeline Marble?)
Grammar books of Henry Noble Day family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession contains a series of sermons preached by Jeremiah Day.

did.unittitle: Twenty-three sermons preached by Jeremiah Day at Danbury and New Preston, Connecticut

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of papers related to various Day family members. The majority of the papers relate to Jeremiah Day (1773-1867) and generally consist of family correspondence concerning health and religion, while other letters relate to Jeremiah Day's presidencies of Yale College and Andover Theological School and his business interests. Other papers related to Jeremiah Day include a partial account book, bills, wills, and other financial documents. Finally, the accession includes correspondence among other Day family members including Henry Noble Day (1808-1890) and Thomas Day (1777-1855) and a booklet of religious reflections written by Jeremiah Day (1737-1806).

did.unittitle: Day, Henry Noble (1808-1890), correspondence with Mills Day and Elizabeth Day
Day, Jane Louisa Marble (wife of Henry Noble Day), The Literary Remains of Martha Day: With Rev. Dr. Fitch's Address at Her Funeral; and Sketches of Her Character
Day, Jeremiah (1737-1806), booklet of religious reflections
Bills, wills, and financial documents connected to estate
Thomas Day (1777-1855), correspondence with Jeremiah and Abigail Day and Mills Day

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of two carte-de-visites of Jeremiah Day (BA 1795), the president of Yale College from 1817 to 1846, and his wife, Olivia Jones Day.
